Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: Experimental Studies of Dilute Pyroclastic Density Currents
Award.AbstractNarration:
Pyroclastic density currents are hot and fast-moving mixtures of solid particles and gas produced by explosive volcanic eruptions or the collapse of lava domes. They travel great distances, pose substantial hazards, and alter landscapes. The processes governing the movement of, and transport in, pyroclastic density currents are not well understood quantitatively. Even conceptual models remain controversial. Basic questions remain about how hills, ridges, and valleys alter and direct pyroclastic density currents and about how air mixes into the currents. These key processes control current speed, direction, and injection of ash into the atmosphere. The long term outcome of better understanding pyroclastic density currents is a scientific foundation for assessing the hazards they pose.

This project will use dynamically scaled laboratory experiments, in particular their interaction with topography, to understand pyroclastic density current dynamics. This will be accomplished by imaging the three-dimensional velocity and concentration fields inside modeled dilute pyroclastic density currents, and quantifying the entrainment of air and sedimentation of particles. This understanding will improve our ability to relate field deposits to the dynamics of these currents. The experimental setup is designed to permit a large number of experiments and hence to explore relationships between parameters and processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Pyroclastic density currents (PDCs) are hot and fast-moving mixtures of solid particles and gas produced by volcanic eurptions. These currents can travel gerat distances, surmount large topographic barriers, pose substantial hazard, and significnatly alter landscapes. PDCs also entrain, heat, and expand air, often resulting in liftoff of portions of the currents as buoyant plumes. Understanding how currents interact with topography and how they entrain air is required for predicting their behavior and interpreting their deposits. This proposal used a series of scaled experiments to examine PDCs through a series of questions:

What are the entrainment coefficients for three-dimensional PDCs? How does the presence or absence of topography affect entrainment and velocity structures within PDCs? How does particle sedimentation record current behavior and interactions with topography?

Our results show that entrainment is not constant, but rather increases with PDC temperature - thus hot currents entrain air faster than cool currents. This means that, all else being equal, a hot PDC will travel less far than a cooler one. In addition, our work shows that entrainment is generally enhanced by topography, such that when a current surmounts a ridge, it will entrain more air.

Our experimental results provide new methods for quantitatively estimating the internal velocity, density, and temperature structure of PDCs based upon video observations of current exteriors. Understanding the internal structure is vital for forecasting the behavior of PDCs, but direct observations of the interiors is presently impossible. 

Analysis of of experiments and their resulting deposits provides a new method for estimating the duration, intensity, steadiness, and temperature of ancient eruptions. All of that information, in turn, can lead to improved forecasting of future eruptive behavior.

In the course of this project, we ran a 2-day public outreach event at the National Museum of Natural History (NMNH) descibing the 1980 eurptino of Mount St. Helens. We produced a live webcast (Smithsonian Science How) for K-12 audiences with live viewship of ~7000; this program discussed volcanoes in general, and pyroclastic flows in particular.
